intro: Tapinanthus guerichii, commonly known as the parasitic dodder, is a flowering plant in the family Orobanchaceae. It is a hemiparasitic plant, meaning it derives some of its nutrients from a host plant while also performing photosynthesis. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers and has a unique appearance with its wiry, vine-like stems. It typically parasitizes woody plants and is found in various regions of Africa. Its botanical significance lies in its parasitic nature and its role in ecological interactions within its habitat.
